title: Pattern Recognition for Neuroimaging Toolbox

author: Jessica Schrouff, Cyclotron Research Center, University of Liège

segmentation: Hi I'm a Jessica skruf.
I'm from the University of Liege in Belgium and I will present you pronto.
The pattern recognition for newer imaging toolbox.
So I this toolbox is aims at linking the machine learning and neuroscience communities.
So during the past decade machine learning models I've been more and more used to analyze neuroscience data.
Very few softwares existing but they are not fully flexible or they require programming skills, which often psychologists or medical doctors don't have.
So here the aim was to build a software that would.
Provide a framework for them to analyze the data using machine learning models.
So the software is.
Is organized in the five main models, so you will have the inputs on top and the modules in blue and they are really classic models with the data in design feature set.
Specify model and run model.
They are designed to be really flexible so they could do.
Consider any problem.
And we have outputs.
An optional review.
Options.
So in the next.

In the user point of view, we have graphical interfaces so you can see on the left the main window in the middle the results window with the predictions on top and the weights of the linear SVM model.
And so these are button pushes, so they like it.

But we also have a batching system on the right, so this was developed by Volckmar Gloc and we're using it in Matlab to to help people that already have a certain background in the programming to automatize some analysis.
But I guess you not potential pronto users, but more likely to be potential contributors to pronto and so that's why.
It's also important that we are here presenting the work.
So what we have now is something with.
SVM, Gaussian processes.
So it's basically it's nothing you, it's just that we need to transform all the inputs and to have these models to be applied to neuroimaging data, which is a specific problem.
But when you develop problem algorithms for machine learning then it would.
It might be really interesting to have them tested on this kind of data because, well, it's a completely different world.
But it could be useful.
So we developed the toolbox to be also easily contributed to.
So we have a.

We use machine libraries, so if you provide the library with all the input it needs and the output should provide, then we can easily put that all in pronto an it would be made available to the new scientific community.
So if you want to know more and maybe to contribute.
Then you can come at the post.
Thank you.
